content.raw: Hey Jason, Is it possible for you to merge or review the pull request #19, since that pull request have proposed some changes to jliang_model branch to improve the controller part and make the robot able to walk.
content.html: Hey Jason, Is it possible for you to merge or review the pull request #19, since that pull request have proposed some changes to jliang_model branch to improve the controller part and make the robot able to walk.

content.raw:
I have merged your pull request into jliang_model.

There are a few issues I notice:

1. It seems that joint->SetAngle() in Robocup3dsPlugin.cc is deprecated, could you change it to something else? 

2. You need to set the iMin/iMax and cmdMax/cmdMin values for the PID below, by default they are all zeros, which is not what we want:

```
#!c++

  protected: std::map<std::string, gazebo::common::PID>
  hingeJointPIDMap =
  {
      {"HeadYaw", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"HeadPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LShoulderPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LShoulderRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LElbowYaw", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LElbowRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LHipYawPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LHipRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LHipPitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"LKneePitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"LAnklePitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"LAnkleRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RHipYawPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RHipRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RHipPitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"RKneePitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"RAnklePitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"RAnkleRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RShoulderPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RShoulderRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RElbowYaw", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RElbowRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)}
  };
```
content.html:
I have merged your pull request into jliang_model.

There are a few issues I notice:

  1. It seems that joint->SetAngle() in Robocup3dsPlugin.cc is deprecated, could you change it to something else?

  2. You need to set the iMin/iMax and cmdMax/cmdMin values for the PID below, by default they are all zeros, which is not what we want:

  protected: std::map<std::string, gazebo::common::PID>
  hingeJointPIDMap =
  {
      {"HeadYaw", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"HeadPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LShoulderPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LShoulderRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LElbowYaw", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LElbowRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LHipYawPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LHipRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"LHipPitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"LKneePitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"LAnklePitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"LAnkleRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RHipYawPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RHipRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RHipPitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"RKneePitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"RAnklePitch", gazebo::common::PID(400, 400, 0)},
      {"RAnkleRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RShoulderPitch", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RShoulderRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RElbowYaw", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)},
      {"RElbowRoll", gazebo::common::PID(160, 160, 0)}
  };

content.raw:
I have also updated the configuration variables, so that now, you only need to specify three values, P gain, I gain, and D gain, for each joint in robocup3d.world. 

Integral and command limits are by default, 1 and 1000 respectively.
content.html:
I have also updated the configuration variables, so that now, you only need to specify three values, P gain, I gain, and D gain, for each joint in robocup3d.world.

Integral and command limits are by default, 1 and 1000 respectively.

content.raw: I think Integral and command limits has done the same role that the <effort> of SDF file has. I tuned the controller based on effort value, in my test when I assigned the limits of PIDs, the controller could not works well, even with the using the same <effort> and SDF file. Did you test the merged version that the robot could walk and spawn using the sample agent?
content.html: I think Integral and command limits has done the same role that the <effort> of SDF file has. I tuned the controller based on effort value, in my test when I assigned the limits of PIDs, the controller could not works well, even with the using the same <effort> and SDF file. Did you test the merged version that the robot could walk and spawn using the sample agent?

content.raw: Does the effort change the value the integral and command limits for the PID controllers?
content.html: Does the effort change the value the integral and command limits for the PID controllers?

content.raw: yes, I think it is possible. In my test I did the reverse, by changing the PID controllers limits, the effect of the effort parameters have been changed. I think these types of the limits should be assigned in one place, e.g. in the SDF file.
content.html: yes, I think it is possible. In my test I did the reverse, by changing the PID controllers limits, the effect of the effort parameters have been changed. I think these types of the limits should be assigned in one place, e.g. in the SDF file.

content.raw: Also checked that it doesn't explode on default. It just falls on the floor and shakes.
content.html: Also checked that it doesn't explode on default. It just falls on the floor and shakes.

content.raw: using the ODE's default step size, 0.001 or lower the simulator will not be crashed. If  it doesn't explode, the sample agent will fall and shake since in this branch the Aldebaran NAO model has been used and the sample agent is developed to work with simspark model.
content.html: using the ODE's default step size, 0.001 or lower the simulator will not be crashed. If it doesn't explode, the sample agent will fall and shake since in this branch the Aldebaran NAO model has been used and the sample agent is developed to work with simspark model.

content.html: Got it, thanks. Should the step size be changed in this PR then?

content.raw: I should add a warning that when using the default step size, loading more than 2-3 agents in the world will lead to significant slowdown.
content.html: I should add a warning that when using the default step size, loading more than 2-3 agents in the world will lead to significant slowdown.

content.raw: I dont know exactly what is the PR, maybe it is <real_time_update_rate>. In my test on this branch and in Nima_Integration branch, I did not assign the <real_time_update_rate>, so gazebo attempted to run the simulation as fast as possible and the simulation goes faster. we should see the effect of this change in challenging behavior like walking.
content.html: I dont know exactly what is the PR, maybe it is <real_time_update_rate>. In my test on this branch and in Nima_Integration branch, I did not assign the <real_time_update_rate>, so gazebo attempted to run the simulation as fast as possible and the simulation goes faster. we should see the effect of this change in challenging behavior like walking.

content.raw:
Usually, a line after loading the world, such as:

`this->world->Step(1)`

Triggers the load of the plugins by the physics. This is a good idea because after that, you know that your plugin is running, otherwise you don't have guarantees.

If I enable this line, the `TestLoadConnectAgent` test fails which make me think that we might have some problem or in the test or in the code. @jasonzliang, could you take a look at this?
content.html:
Usually, a line after loading the world, such as:

this->world->Step(1)

Triggers the load of the plugins by the physics. This is a good idea because after that, you know that your plugin is running, otherwise you don't have guarantees.

If I enable this line, the TestLoadConnectAgent test fails which make me think that we might have some problem or in the test or in the code. @jasonzliang, could you take a look at this?

content.raw:
OK, I ran the integration tests one by one and they seem to work. I still have some questions before approving this pull request:

* I see the following messages in some of the tests:

```
#!c++
(SelectInput) select failed Success
error receiving msg!
```
Is this expected? If not, can we change/remove the message, it's confusing.

* Usually, a line after loading the world, such as:

`this->world->Step(1)`

triggers the load of the plugins by the physics. This is a good idea because after that, you know that your plugin is running, otherwise you don't have guarantees.

If I enable this line in `run_agent.cc::TestLoadConnectAgent`, the test fails which make me think that we might have some problem or in the test or in the code. jasonzliang, could you take a look at this?

* I can load a team of agents using the utaustinvilla script. If I'am not wrong this is loading the Aldebaran Nao model. How can I test the Nao type Zero model?
content.html:
OK, I ran the integration tests one by one and they seem to work. I still have some questions before approving this pull request:

  • I see the following messages in some of the tests:
(SelectInput) select failed Success
error receiving msg!

Is this expected? If not, can we change/remove the message, it's confusing.

  • Usually, a line after loading the world, such as:

this->world->Step(1)

triggers the load of the plugins by the physics. This is a good idea because after that, you know that your plugin is running, otherwise you don't have guarantees.

If I enable this line in run_agent.cc::TestLoadConnectAgent, the test fails which make me think that we might have some problem or in the test or in the code. jasonzliang, could you take a look at this?

  • I can load a team of agents using the utaustinvilla script. If I'am not wrong this is loading the Aldebaran Nao model. How can I test the Nao type Zero model?

content.raw:
I have removed the print statement in 2fb13b8b4a5e

The problem with 
```
#!c++

this->world->Step(1)
```
is that for some reason after executing this statement, Robocup3dsPlugin::Update() is no longer being called every cycle, meaning that the server plugin has essentially stopped running. I do not know the reason why, but I dont believe this is a problem with the plugin or the test. Also, I am not sure if this is the right way to use
```
#!c++

this->world->Step()
```
since I am getting the following warning: 


```
#!c++

[Wrn] [World.cc:730] Calling World::Step(steps) while world is not paused

```

If you want to test the Nao type Zero model, change the following line in GameState.cc 

```
#!c++

defaultBodyType(agentBodyTypeMap.at("NaoOfficialBT"))
```

to

```
#!c++

defaultBodyType(agentBodyTypeMap.at("NaoSimsparkBT"))
```
content.html:
I have removed the print statement in 2fb13b8b4a5e

The problem with 

this->world->Step(1)

is that for some reason after executing this statement, Robocup3dsPlugin::Update() is no longer being called every cycle, meaning that the server plugin has essentially stopped running. I do not know the reason why, but I dont believe this is a problem with the plugin or the test. Also, I am not sure if this is the right way to use

this->world->Step()

since I am getting the following warning: 

[Wrn] [World.cc:730] Calling World::Step(steps) while world is not paused

If you want to test the Nao type Zero model, change the following line in GameState.cc 

defaultBodyType(agentBodyTypeMap.at("NaoOfficialBT"))

to

defaultBodyType(agentBodyTypeMap.at("NaoSimsparkBT"))

content.raw:

content.raw:
This maybe happen occasionally due to the slowdowns or network latency. I am normally expecting the server to send a message to the client every 20 miliseconds, but sometimes it might take longer. It prints 
```
#!c++

error receiving msg! 
```
when it happens
content.html:

when it happens
